awd_titl_txt: Behavior and regularity properties of solutions of fluid equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Kukavica
1615239

     The investigator studies the properties of solutions of equations that describe the motion of fluids.  He considers the Navier-Stokes system, which is the principal model for motion of a viscous incompressible fluid, the Prandtl equations (a boundary-layer approximation for Navier-Stokes), the Euler equations (roughly speaking, Navier-Stokes with zero viscosity), and the primitive equations, which represent large-scale motion of the ocean and atmosphere.  He analyzes fluid-structure interactions between a fluid and an elastic solid, other problems involving free boundaries, the limiting behavior of viscous fluids in the presence of boundaries as the viscosity goes to zero, and the regularity and long-time behavior of solutions.  Results expand our understanding of fluid flow problems arising in geosciences, engineering, and other areas, especially in connection with control and numerical methods.  Graduate students are involved in the work of the project.

     The main goal of the project is the study of the qualitative properties and regularity of solutions of equations arising in fluid dynamics.  While the primary focus is placed on the Navier-Stokes equations, the investigator considers also related models such as the Euler system, Prandtl equations, and the primitive equations of the ocean and the atmosphere.  A special emphasis is systems involving a fluid (compressible or incompressible) and an elastic solid.  Here the main aim is to investigate the local and global well-posedness of solutions as well as their large-time behavior when they exist.  The investigator also studies the vanishing viscosity problem in domains with boundaries, using the properties of the local asymptotics.  The main goal here is to better understand the solutions of the Prandtl equation and to identify their role in the vanishing viscosity limit.  The last part of the project concerns the local properties of solutions of the partial differential equations modeling fluids, in particular their analytic and Gevrey regularity, unique continuation, and their long time behavior.  Graduate students are involved in the work of the project.

por.por_cntn:
The project considered solutions of PDE which describe motion of a fluid. The primary model describing the motion of a fluid is the Navier-Stokes system, but other related models were also studied, namely the Prandtl equations (the system describing the motion of an incompressible fluid close to the boundary), the Euler equations (the inviscid version of the equations), and the super-critical quasi-geostrophic equation (a 2D model for 3D behavior of fluids).  Also, the fluid-structure type systems were considered. Here the fluid is interacting with an immersed elastic body. Also, the models involving stochastic forcing were addressed.


Intellectual Merit: 

The PI, all jointly with collaborators and students, obtained the following results.  For the deterministic Navier-Stokes equations, the PI obtained the anisotropic criteria for the regularity of the Navier-Stokes equations. The conditions are based only on one component of the solution. The free boundary Euler equations were considered and the regularity was obtained under the physical assumption of positive surface tension with the minimal requirement on the initial velocity in the domain. Also the local existence was obtained for intermittent data. Here the initial data has minimal local requirements on the velocity, allowing for the growth at infinity.  We addressed the regularity for the quasi-geostrophic equation, and the following partial regularity result was obtained: For the slightly super-critical QGE, the solution must be regular except on a compact set in space and time.
For the fluid-structure model, the primary physical model studied is the one when the elastic body is interacting with a surrounding incompressible fluid. It is an open problem whether the solutions exist for all time or they only exist for a short time given sufficiently regular data. It was proven that for small data and under an interior stabilization effect, the solutions exist for all time. This is the first result of global existence for this type of model.  For the stochastic PDEs, we studied the existence of an invariant measures for dispersive PDE, convergence of an approximating system to the stochastic Navier-Stokes equations was obtained, as well as a sharp local existence theorem for the stochastic Euler equations with Levy noise was established.  In addition, we obtained an ill-posedness of the Prandtl boundary layer equations under nonzero boundary Euler data, confirming a conjecture based on earlier numerical experiments by Van Dommelen and Shen. 

 

Broader Impact:

Overall six graduate students were involved in the project, two obtaining the Ph.D with PI as an adviser and three working on their Ph.D. thesis. The project also involved thirteen collaborators in different institutions.  The PI and his graduate students gave numerous talks at conferences and seminars and coorganized workshops and conferences.
